headline: No, an Arizona governor cannot complete the border wall without the Fed's permission
sentences:
US Customs and border patrol
Aaron Reichlin Melnick with the American Immigration Council
FALSE
Completing the wall on Arizona's border would require building on federal and tribal land.
“The remaining sections of the wall that could be built are almost universally on federal or tribal lands.” Reichlin-Melnick said.
"The state of Arizona could theoretically build a border wall 50 miles away on state land, but why would they do that?
Multiple republican gubernatorial candidates have promised to finish the border wall on Arizona's southern border.
The federal government controls almost everything else, and a state cannot force either to hand over the land.
For example, the Tohono O’Odham nation has around 60 miles of Arizona's un-walled border and opposes a wall.
"The state government cannot use the power of eminent domain to seize land and use it as it likes.
However, there are only around 18 miles of the un-walled border in Arizona is on private land.
“Where are they going to build it, and how could they build it?” Reichlin-Melnick said.
Texas is constructing a wall on its southern border mainly building on private land.
In a tweet, Kari Lake said, "Yes, we will finish the wall on State AND Federal land.
The state does not have legal permission to build on that land without permission.
Can a governor finish the border wall without the federal government's permission?
ARIZONA, USA — A former president Trump rally cry has become a campaign promise.
First, we need to understand what Arizona's border is like right now.
Most of Arizona's border already has some kind of barrier on it.

Text the number below:
Did you miss one of our Verify segments?
It needs permission from the federal government to do that."
You can find all of our VERIFY stories on this playlist.
And No, I will not be asking permission from the Feds.
Is Joe Biden going to arrest a sitting Governor?
Building on private lands can be easier.
Have a claim you'd like us to VERIFY?
Reichlin Melnick said.
Reichlin-Melnick said.
Try me."
